title: H-block cross-validation
text: use foraminifera dataset Kucera et al. (2005). split dataset two parts, North Atlantic (NA) dataset (north 3°N) South Atlantic (SA) data set (south 3°S). use NA dataset training set SA dataset spatially independent test set. First, estimate performance North Atlantic (NA) foraminifera training set applied spatially independent data set South Atlantic (SA), case contains samples used Kucera et al. (2005) situated south 3°S. RMSEP NA training set 1.28 RMSEP spatially independent SA data set somewhat larger: 2.1. indicative spatial autocorrelation. find removal distance h h-block cross-validated RMSEP RMSEP SA test set similar. Figure 1: Root mean square error prediction (RMSEP) function removal distance h. Dashed horizontal line indicates RMSEP found spatially independent test set. Using linear interpolation, h-block distance 761 km gives cross-validated RMSEP equivalent RMSEP spatially independent test set.
code: # load data data(Atlantic) meta <- c("Core", "Latitude", "Longitude", "summ50")  # N Atlantic N_Atlantic <- Atlantic |>   filter(Latitude > 3) |>   slice_sample(n = 300) # subsample for speed N_Atlantic_meta <- N_Atlantic |>   select(one_of(meta)) |>   as.data.frame() # to keep rdist.earth happy N_Atlantic <- N_Atlantic |>   select(-one_of(meta))  # S Atlantic S_Atlantic <- Atlantic |>   filter(Latitude < -3) S_Atlantic_meta <- S_Atlantic |>   select(one_of(meta)) S_Atlantic <- S_Atlantic |>   select(-one_of(meta))  ## convert N_Atlatic_meta to an sf object  N_Atlantic_meta <- st_as_sf(   x = N_Atlantic_meta,   coords = c("Longitude", "Latitude"),   crs = 4326 )   # calculating distances among the sampled points in the # North Atlantic foraminifera data set geodist <- st_distance(N_Atlantic_meta) |>   units::set_units("km") |>   units::set_units(NULL)  # values of h for which h-block cross-validation is calculated threshs <- c(0.01, 300, 600, 900, 1200)  # h-block cross-validation of the NA foraminifera dataset for # different values of h res_h <- map(threshs, function(h) {   mod <- MAT(N_Atlantic, N_Atlantic_meta$summ50, k = 5, lean = FALSE)   mod <- crossval(mod, cv.method = "h-block", h.dist = geodist, h.cutoff = h)    tibble(     h = h,     RMSE = performance(mod)$crossval["N05", "RMSE"],     R2 = performance(mod)$crossval["N05", "R2"]   ) }) |>   list_rbind() # Leave-one-out cross-validated RMSEP using MAT with k = 5 round(res_h[1, "RMSE"], 2) # Predicting the South Atlantic test set mod_NA <- MAT(N_Atlantic, N_Atlantic_meta$summ50, k = 5) pred_SA <- predict(mod_NA, newdata = S_Atlantic)$fit # Determining RMSEP of the SA test set rmse_mat <- sqrt(mean((pred_SA[, 1] - S_Atlantic_meta$summ50)^2)) # RMSEP of the SA test set using MAT with k = 5 round(rmse_mat, 2)

title: H-block cross-validation
text: second method proposed Trachsel Telford fit variogram detrended residuals weighted average model use range variogram h. Figure 2: Semi-variogram fitted detrended residuals weighted averaging model. estimated range spherical variogram model fitted detrended residual WA model 794 km.
code: # WA model modwa <- crossval(WA(sqrt(N_Atlantic), N_Atlantic_meta$summ50, mono = TRUE)) # residuals of the WA model wa_resid <- residuals(modwa, cv = TRUE) # detrend to remove edge effects (loess with span = 0.1) detrended_resid <- resid(loess(wa_resid[, 1] ~ N_Atlantic_meta$summ50,   span = 0.1 ))  # variogram of the detrended residuals of the WA model v <- variogram(detrended_resid ~ 1, data = N_Atlantic_meta) # Fitting a spherical variogram (partial sill, range and nugget are # approximately estimated from the empirical variogram) vm <- fit.variogram(v, vgm(psill = 2, "Sph", range = 1500, nugget = 0.5)) plot(v, vm)

title: H-block cross-validation
text: third method suggested based simulated environmental variables spatial structure environmental variable interest. transfer function performance (r2) simulated variable compared r2 environmental variable interest simulated variables. optimal value h value minimises difference two r2. simulate environmental variables interest, first estimate spatial structure variogram use kriging variogram simulate environmental variables spatial structure observed variable. Figure 3: Semi-variogram model (Matérn class) fitted North Atlantic summer sea temperature 50 m depth. Running MAT models simulation value h slow, since analogues chosen environmental variable, can make much faster version MAT. Figure 5: Scatterplot squared correlation coefficients simulated variables environmental variable interest transfer function r2. Figure 6: Relationship sum squares two r2 function distance h. Following rule described Trachsel Telford value h estimated h = 900 km. Hence three methods proposed result similar values h: h = 761 km spatially independent test set, h = 794 km variogram range method h = 900 km variance explained method.
code: # Estimate the variogram model for the environmental variable of interest ve <- variogram(summ50 ~ 1, data = N_Atlantic_meta) vem <- fit.variogram(ve, vgm(40, "Mat", 5000, .1, kappa = 1.8)) plot(ve, vem) # Simulating environmental variables sim <- krige(sim ~ 1,   locations = N_Atlantic_meta,   dummy = TRUE,   nsim = 100,   beta = mean(N_Atlantic_meta$summ50),   model = vem,   newdata = N_Atlantic_meta ) #> [using unconditional Gaussian simulation]  # convert back to a regular data.frame sim <- sim |>   st_drop_geometry() # Function for h-block cross-validating several simulations at a time mat_h1 <- function(y, x, noanalogues, geodist, thresh) {   if (!inherits(y, "dist")) {     if (is.data.frame(y) || !(ncol(y) == nrow(y) && sum(diag(y)) == 0)) {       y <- dist(sqrt(y))^2 # squared chord distance     }   }   y <- as.matrix(y)   diag(y) <- Inf   if (inherits(geodist, "dist")) {     geodist <- as.matrix(geodist)   }   sapply(seq_len(nrow(y)), function(n) {     exneigh <- geodist[n, ] >= thresh     x2 <- x[exneigh, ]     y2 <- y[n, ][exneigh]     analogues <- which(rank(y2, ties.method = "random") <= noanalogues)     colMeans(x2[analogues, ])   }) }   # h-block cross-validation of the simulated variables simhr <- sapply(threshs, function(h) {   hn <- mat_h1(N_Atlantic, sim, noanalogues = 5, geodist = geodist, thresh = h)   diag(cor(t(hn), sim)^2) })  # Estimating squared correlation between environmental variable of interest and # simulated variables sim_obs_r2 <- sapply(sim, cor, N_Atlantic_meta$summ50)^2 # Calculating sum of squares between the two squared correlations so_squares <- apply(simhr, 2, function(x) {   sum((x - sim_obs_r2)^2) }) simhr |>   as.data.frame() |>   set_names(threshs) |>   mutate(sim_obs_r2 = sim_obs_r2) |>   pivot_longer(cols = -sim_obs_r2, names_to = "h", values_to = "value") |>   mutate(h = factor(h, levels = threshs)) |>   ggplot(aes(x = sim_obs_r2, y = value)) +   geom_point() +   geom_abline() +   facet_wrap(~h) +   labs(x = "Simulated-observed environmental r²", y = "Transfer function r²") tibble(threshs, so_squares) |>   ggplot(aes(x = threshs, y = so_squares)) +   geom_point() +   labs(x = "h km", y = "Sum of squares")

title: H-block cross-validation
text: Kucera, M., Weinelt, M., Kiefer, T., Pflaumann, U., Hayes, ., Weinelt, M., Chen, M.-T., Mix, .C., Barrows, T.T., Cortijo, E., Duprat, J., Juggins, S., Waelbroeck, C. 2005. Reconstruction glacial Atlantic Pacific sea-surface temperatures assemblages planktonic foraminifera: multi-technique approach based geographically constrained calibration datasets. Quaternary Science Reviews 24, 951-998 doi:10.1016/j.quascirev.2004.07.014. Telford, R.J., Birks, H.J.B. 2009. Evaluation transfer functions spatially structured environments. Quaternary Science Reviews 28, 1309-1316 doi:10.1016/j.quascirev.2008.12.020. Trachsel, M., Telford, R.J. (2016). Technical note: Estimating unbiased transfer function performances spatially structured environments. submitted : Climate Past 12, 1215-1223 doi:10.5194/cp-12-1215-2016

title: randomTF on spatially structured environments
text: use foraminifera dataset Kucera et al. (2005). use samples represent core.
code: # load data data(Atlantic) meta <- c("Core", "Latitude", "Longitude", "summ50") Atlantic <- as.data.frame(Atlantic) # prevents rowname warnings  # pseudocore as no fossil foram data in palaeoSig fosn <- Atlantic |>   filter(between(summ50, 5, 10)) |>   slice_sample(n = 20)  # remaining samples as training set Atlantic <- Atlantic |>   anti_join(fosn, by = "Core") |>   slice_sample(n = 300) # random subset to speed analysis up  Atlantic_meta <- Atlantic |>   select(one_of(meta)) # to keep rdist.earth happy Atlantic <- Atlantic |> # species   select(-one_of(meta))  fos <- fosn |>   select(-one_of(meta))

title: randomTF on spatially structured environments
text: need convert meta data sf object calculation. Fitting variogram hardest part. several types variogram model available, e.g. exponential “Exp”, spherical “Sph”, gaussian “Gau” Matérn “Mat”. different shapes. important find one fits data well. Figure 1: Semi-variogram model (Matérn class) fitted Atlantic summer sea temperature 50 m depth.
code: Atlantic_meta <- st_as_sf(   x = Atlantic_meta,   coords = c("Longitude", "Latitude"),   crs = 4326 ) # Estimate the variogram model for the environmental variable of interest ve <- variogram(summ50 ~ 1, data = Atlantic_meta) vem <- fit.variogram(   object = ve,   model = vgm(40, "Mat", 5000, .1, kappa = 1.8) ) plot(ve, vem) vem #>   model       psill    range kappa #> 1   Nug   0.7358321    0.000   0.0 #> 2   Mat 185.3131517 3404.449   1.8

title: randomTF on spatially structured environments
text: Now can use gstat::krige Gaussian unconditional simulation make simulated environmental fields spatial structure observed variable. step quite slow large datasets. Now can run randomTF using simulated environmental variables. Figure 2. Result randomTF autocorrelated null model. Figure 3. Result randomTF spatially independent null model.
code: # Simulating environmental variables sim <- krige(sim ~ 1,   locations = Atlantic_meta,   dummy = TRUE,   nsim = 100,   beta = mean(Atlantic_meta$"summ50"),   model = vem,   newdata = Atlantic_meta ) #> [using unconditional Gaussian simulation]  # convert sf back to a regular data.frame sim <- sim |> st_drop_geometry() rtf_auto <- randomTF(   spp = Atlantic,   env = Atlantic_meta$summ50,   fos = fos,   autosim = sim,   fun = MAT,   col = "MAT.wm" ) #> Warning in Merge(object$y, newdata, split = TRUE): Some row names were changed #> to avoid duplicates. #> Warning in Merge(object$y, newdata, split = TRUE): Some row names were changed #> to avoid duplicates.  plot(rtf_auto) rtf_ind <- randomTF(   spp = Atlantic,   env = Atlantic_meta$summ50,   fos = fos,   fun = MAT,   col = "MAT.wm" ) #> Warning in Merge(object$y, newdata, split = TRUE): Some row names were changed #> to avoid duplicates. #> Warning in Merge(object$y, newdata, split = TRUE): Some row names were changed #> to avoid duplicates.  plot(rtf_ind)

title: Authors and Citation
text: Telford RJ, Trachsel M (2023). palaeoSig: Significance Tests Quantitative Palaeoenvironmental Reconstructions. R package version 2.1-3, https://cran.r-project.org/package=palaeoSig.
code: @Manual{,   title = {palaeoSig: Significance Tests of Quantitative Palaeoenvironmental Reconstructions},   author = {Richard James Telford and Mathias Trachsel},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 2.1-3},   url = {https://cran.r-project.org/package=palaeoSig}, }

title: Significance Tests for Palaeoenvironmental Reconstructions
text: PalaeoSig includes methods developed : Telford Birks (2011) testing significance transfer function reconstructions. Telford Birks (2009) evaluating transfer function performance spatially autocorrelated environments. Heegaard et al. (2005) age-depth modelling procedure Minchin (1987) simulation community data, base COMPAS.

title: Significance Tests for Palaeoenvironmental Reconstructions
text: can install released version palaeoSig CRAN : development version GitHub :
code: install.packages("palaeoSig") # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("richardjtelford/palaeoSig")

what: Estimation of the relationship between Calibrated age and depth — agelme
title: Estimation of the relationship between Calibrated age and depth — agelme
text: Estimates relationship Calibrated age depth palaeorecords. function uses smooth spline mgcv library Simon Wood. produces predicted confidence interval relationship approximating mixed effect model, two levels uncertainty, .e. within dated object dated objects.

title: Estimation of the relationship between Calibrated age and depth — agelme
code: agelme(   depup,   depdo,   bpup,   bpdo,   use,   weights = c(1, rep(0, length(depup) - 1)),   vspan = 1,   k = length(depup) - 1,   m = 2,   diagnostic = FALSE )

title: Estimation of the relationship between Calibrated age and depth — agelme
text: depup upper depths dated slides depdo lower depths dated slides bpup younger calibrated ages dated slides bpdo older calibrated ages dated slides use Logical vector dates include model. Default use . weights Weights used estimation, default fixed top-layer followed inverse variance within dated object vspan span used diagnostic plots, default span = 1 k Number base function start shrinkage gam estimation procedure m order penalty term, .e. degree continuity knots (default, m = 2 gives cubic smooth spline) diagnostic Logical, diagnostic plots made.

title: Estimation of the relationship between Calibrated age and depth — agelme
text: list class 'agelme' following items: tdf Degrees freedom used cubic smooth spline, vector first value constant variance second vector variance equal mu. weights vector weights used cubic smooth spline Constant matrix numerical results dated points using constant variance Muvar matrix numerical results dated points using variance equal mu RES vector Residual sum squares Models list models cubic smooth spline, constant mu variance, respectively Data data.frame including data used estimation

title: Estimation of the relationship between Calibrated age and depth — agelme
text: Note fixation top layer done weight = 1, whereas weights follows inverse variance within object. diagnostic plots used check quality estimation see need assumption object variance proportional mean. latter however rarely encountered palaeodata.

title: Estimation of the relationship between Calibrated age and depth — agelme
text: Heegaard, E., Birks, HJB. & Telford, RJ. 2005. Relationships calibrated ages depth stratigraphical sequences: estimation procedure mixed-effect regression. Holocene 15: 612-618 doi:10.1191/0959683605hl836rr

title: Estimation of the relationship between Calibrated age and depth — agelme
text: Einar Heegaard

title: Estimation of the relationship between Calibrated age and depth — agelme
code: data(STOR)  fit.mod <- with(STOR, agelme(depthup, depthdo, cageup, cagedo))  # Predicting using the constant variance model, # for each cm between 70 and 400 cm. fit.pre <- predict(fit.mod, 1, 70:400) plot(fit.pre)

code: set.seed(42) x <- c(rnorm(50, 0, 1), rnorm(50, 6, 1)) hist(x)  ana.fun <- anamorph(x, 30, plot = TRUE)  xg <- ana.fun$xtog(x) qqnorm(xg) qqline(xg)  all.equal(x, ana.fun$gtox(xg)) #> [1] TRUE

what: Test if two variables jointly control changes in fossil data — jointsig
title: Test if two variables jointly control changes in fossil data — jointsig
text: Generates synthetic variables different proportion two environmental variables, tests much variance fossil data reconstructions synthetic variables explain.

title: Test if two variables jointly control changes in fossil data — jointsig
code: jointsig(spp, fos, var1, var2, method = "randomTF", n = 99, r = 32, ...)  # S3 method for class 'js' plot(x, names.v1, names.v2, ...)

title: Test if two variables jointly control changes in fossil data — jointsig
text: spp Data frame modern training set species data, transformed required, example sqrt fos Data frame fossil species data, species codes transformations spp var1 Training set environmental variable 1 var2 Training set environmental variable 2 method significance test use. Current option randomTF obs.cor. latter may give strange results - use caution. n number random training sets used generate null model r many synthetic variables make. better slower ... arguments plot x Output jointsig names.v1 Vector length 2 names end members first environmental variable, e.g., c("cold", "warm") temperature. names.v2 Ditto second variable.

title: Test if two variables jointly control changes in fossil data — jointsig
text: list components PCA unconstrained ordination fossil data. preds list containing reconstructions environmental variable. MAX Proportion variance explained first axis unconstrained ordination. maximum amount reconstruction single variable can explain. EX proportion variance fossil data explained reconstruction. sim.ex proportion variance explained random environmental variables. sig p-value reconstruction.

title: Test if two variables jointly control changes in fossil data — jointsig
text: method="randomTF", function calculates proportion variance fossil data explained transfer function reconstructions synthetic variables. synthetic variables composed two environmental variables, weighted -1 +1, represent circle. compared null distribution proportion variance explained reconstructions based random environmental variables. transfer function rioja library can used. method="obs.cor", aim , function reports correlation species weighted average optima synthetic variables species first axis scores. option pathological behaviour probably avoided.

title: Test if two variables jointly control changes in fossil data — jointsig
text: plot(js): Plot js object

title: Test if two variables jointly control changes in fossil data — jointsig
text: Unpublished method - use caution. Can give spurious results weighted averaging.

title: Test if two variables jointly control changes in fossil data — jointsig
text: Richard Telford richard.telford@bio.uib.

title: Test if two variables jointly control changes in fossil data — jointsig
code: require(rioja) data(SWAP) data(RLGH)  rlgh.js <- jointsig(   spp = sqrt(SWAP$spec),   fos = sqrt(RLGH$spec),   var1 = SWAP$pH,   var2 = sample(SWAP$pH),   method = "randomTF",   n = 49, r = 32, fun = WA, col = 1 ) # nonsense second variable  plot(rlgh.js, c("acid", "alkaline"), c("down", "up"))

Single number vector length ndim. edistr Distribution environmental variables. Currently 'uniform' 'Gaussian' supported. ecor Correlation matrix environmental variables supplied user. title: Function to simulate species data  — make.set
code: calib <- make.set(nspp = 90,ndim = 3,Amax = runif,fun = runif, xpar = c(-50,150),      srange = 400, alpha = 4, gamma = 4,n = 100,elen =rep(100,3),emean = rep(50,3),     edistr ='uniform', cnt = 1000)  # Provide species parameters generated above, so that the fossil data use the  #    same species parameters. fos <- make.set(ndim = 3,n = 100,elen =rep(100,3),emean = rep(50,3), edistr ='uniform',     cnt = 1000, spec = calib$spec)    # Supplying own environmental variables and species parameters. env.vars <- make.env(100,elen =rep(100,3),emean = rep(50,3), edistr ='uniform',ndim = 3) fos <- make.set(cnt = 1000, spec = calib$spec, env = env.vars)

title: Weighted correlation between weighted averaging optima and constrained ordination species scores. — obs.cor
text: spp Data frame modern training set species data, transformed required, example sqrt env Vector single environmental variable fos Data frame fossil species data. Species codes transformations match spp. ord Constrained ordination method use. rda default, cca also work. capscale work without modifications code (wrapper). n number random training sets. better. min.occur Minimum number occurrences species species fossil data. autosim Optional data frame random values. useful training set spatially autocorrelated supplied data frame contains autocorrelated random variables. autosim missing, permute FALSE, transfer functions trained random variables drawn uniform distribution. permute logical value. Generate random environmental variables permuting existing variable. possible one environmental variable autosim missing. x obscor object. xlab X-axis label default unsatisfactory. ylab Y-axis label default unsatisfactory. f Scale factor abundances, maximum cex points =1 plot. type plot. = 1 gives plot RDA scores species optima. = 2 gives histogram showing null distribution correlations RDA scores species optima, together observed correlation. variable_names Name environmental variable (1 currently) label observed correlation = 2 abun species weighting required plots. See details p_val P value draw line vertical line (=2) ... arguments plot identify labels Labels points identify. default, species names intersection colnames(spp) colnames(fos) used. object obscor object. nbins integer giving number bins histogram top Proportion figure environmental name labels.

title: Weighted correlation between weighted averaging optima and constrained ordination species scores. — obs.cor
text: obs.cor returns obscor object, list ob Observed correlation. Data.frame columns Optima, RDA1 abun containing species optima, ordination axis 1 scores, abundance used weight species respectively vector containing weighted unweighted correlations species optima ordination scores. sim Matrix correlation species weighted average optima ordination scores first column weighted correlation second column. row represents different random environmental variable. sigs p-value observed correlation species weighted average optima ordination scores weights.

title: Weighted correlation between weighted averaging optima and constrained ordination species scores. — obs.cor
text: Obs.cor calculates (weighted) correlation species WA optima calibration set ordination axis one scores fossil data. Seven different weights species implemented. "abun.fos" - weight mean abundance fossil data. "abun.calib" - weight mean abundance calibration data "abun.joint" - weight product mean abundance fossil calibration data "n2.fos" - weight effective number occurrences (Hill's N2) species fossil data "n2.calib" - weight effective number occurrences (Hill's N2) species calibration data "n2.joint" - weight product n2.calib n2.fos "unweighted" - species receive weight. unlikely best option included completeness. unclear weights likely best: research progress. square root transformation species data often useful. n = 99 small practice give smooth histogram null model. n = 999 better.

title: Weighted correlation between weighted averaging optima and constrained ordination species scores. — obs.cor

code: require(rioja) data(SWAP) data(RLGH) rlgh.obs <- obs.cor(   spp = sqrt(SWAP$spec),   env = SWAP$pH,   fos = sqrt(RLGH$spec),   n = 49 # low number for speed ) rlgh.obs$sig #>   abun.fos abun.calib abun.joint     n2.fos   n2.calib   n2.joint unweighted  #>       0.02       0.02       0.02       0.02       0.02       0.02       1.00  plot(rlgh.obs, which = 1)  plot(rlgh.obs, which = 2)   require(ggplot2) #> Loading required package: ggplot2 autoplot(rlgh.obs, which = 1)  autoplot(rlgh.obs, which = 2, variable_names = "pH")

text: spp Data frame modern training set species data, transformed required example sqrt env Data frame training set environmental variables vector single environmental variable fos Data frame fossil species data, species codes transformations spp n number random training sets. better. fun Transfer function method. Additional arguments fun can passed ... col transfer functions return one column results, example different WAPLS components. col selects column reconstructions use. See relevant transfer function method help file. condition Optional data frame reconstructions partial testing multiple independent reconstructions possible. autosim Optional data frame random values. useful training set spatially autocorrelated supplied data frame contains autocorrelated random variables. autosim missing, permute FALSE, transfer functions trained random variables drawn uniform distribution. ord Constrained ordination method use. rda default, cca also work. capscale work without modifications code (wrapper). permute logical value. Generate random environmental variables permuting existing variable. possible one environmental variable autosim missing. models list models made randomTF argument make_models = TRUE make_models logical, list transfer functions trained random data returned ... arguments transfer function. example change distance metric MAT. Also extra arguments plot. x Output randomTF variable_names Names environmental variables. missing, taken env data.frame. top Proportion figure environmental name labels. adj Adjust position environmental names plotted . p_val P value draw line vertical line (=2) object Output randomTF nbins integer giving number bins histogram

Reconstructions can partialled test multiple reconstructions statistically significant. environment spatially autocorrelated, red-noise null used instead default white noise null. Red noise environmental variables can generated gstat package. transfer function rioja package can used. methods (e.g. random forests) can used making wrapper function. reconstructions several sites tested using training set can much faster train models random environmental data use repeatedly. can done make_models = TRUE running randomTF giving resultant models models argument. make_models work MAT. transfer function methods, including WA, code can made somewhat faster coercing modern fossil species data matrices (spp <- .matrix(spp)), otherwise WA repeatedly. MAT, done might cause error.

what: Generates species response parameters for n dimensions  — species
title: Generates species response parameters for n dimensions  — species
text: Generates species response parameters n environmental variables following Minchin (1987).

title: Generates species response parameters for n dimensions  — species
code: species(nspp = 30, Amax, fun, xpar, srange, alpha = 4,          gamma= 4, ndim, sdistr, ocor, odistr)

title: Generates species response parameters for n dimensions  — species
text: nspp Number species generated. Amax Maximum abundance species. `Amax` currently allows three options: ) function generate maximum abundances (e.g. `runif`, `rgamma`) ii) vector length `nspp`  iii) single number used maximum abundance species. fun Function generate species optima (e.g. `rnorm`, `runif`). two parameters `xpar` passed function `fun`. omitted species optima generated   regular intervals two values `xpar`. xpar Two numbers describing distribution e.g mu sigma normal distribution, lower upper bound random uniform distribution. srange Length ecological gradient individual species respond. Either one number matrix `nspp` rows `ndim` columns. `srange` different different environmental variables simpler solution change argument elen make.env accordingly. E.g. `elen = c(100,50,50)` using three environmental gradients. alpha Shape parameter beta distribution. One number matrix `nspp` rows `ndim` columns. gamma Shape parameter beta distribution. One number matrix `nspp` rows `ndim` columns. ndim Number environmental variables generated species respond. sdistr Users may supply distributions species optima. Matrix `nspp` rows `ndim` columns (well special case `ndim = 1`). ocor Correlation matrix species optima. May generated code cor.mat.fun. odistr Distribution correlated optima either 'uniform' 'Gaussian'

title: Generates species response parameters for n dimensions  — species
text: Details exact generation species response functions parameters `Amax`, `m`, `r`, `gamma` `alpha` given Minchin (1987). Species response curves determined five parameters: parameter determining maximum abundance (`Amax`) one describing location (`m`) mode. parameter determining environmental range species respond (`srange` input `r` output) two parameters (`alpha`, `gamma`) describing shape species response function. `alpha` = `gamma` response curve symmetric (`alpha` = `gamma` = 4, yields Gaussian distributions). Additionally, species optima several environmental variables may correlated. Currently possible gaussian uniform distributions species optima. Users may well supply previously generated optima (e.g. optima similar real dataset).

title: Generates species response parameters for n dimensions  — species
text: List `ndim` elements. list contains species response parameters one environmental gradient.

title: Generates species response parameters for n dimensions  — species
text: Minchin, P.R. (1987) Multidimensional Community Patterns: Towards Comprehensive Model. Vegetatio, 71, 145-156.

title: Generates species response parameters for n dimensions  — species
text: Mathias Trachsel Richard J. Telford

title: Generates species response parameters for n dimensions  — species
code: spec.par <- species(nspp = 30, Amax = runif, srange = 200, fun = runif, xpar = c(-50, 150),   ndim = 5, alpha = 4, gamma = 4) spec.par <- species(nspp = 30, ndim = 3, Amax = runif, xpar = c(-50, 150),  srange = 200, alpha = 4, gamma = 4)   # example where srange, alpha and gamma are different for each species and environmental gradient.  spec.par <- species(nspp = 30, ndim = 3, Amax = runif, xpar = c(-50, 150),  srange = matrix(ncol = 3, runif(90, 100, 200)), alpha = matrix(ncol = 3, runif(90, 1, 5)),  gamma = matrix(ncol = 3, runif(90, 1, 5)))  # example where species optima are correlated correlations <- list(c(1, 2, 0.5), c(1, 3, 0.3), c(2, 3, 0.1)) spec.cor.mat <- cor.mat.fun(3, correlations) spec.par <- species(nspp = 30, ndim = 3, Amax = runif, xpar = c(50, 50), srange = 200,  alpha = 4, gamma = 4,ocor = spec.cor.mat, odistr = 'Gaussian')             # example for species response curves (users should alter alpha and gamma) spec.par <- species(nspp = 1, Amax = 200, srange = 200, fun = runif, xpar = c(50, 50),       ndim = 1, alpha = 3, gamma = 1) env <- -50:150 response <- palaeoSig:::make.abundances(env = -50:150, param = spec.par[[1]]$spp) plot(env, response, type='l')

title: palaeoSig 2.1-4

title: palaeoSig 2.1-3
text: CRAN release: 2023-03-10 Vignettes work subset data speed.

title: palaeoSig 2.1-2
text: Arguments autoplot() functions changed first now object rather x meet CRAN rules. probably effect anybody unless named first argument.

title: palaeoSig 2.1-1
text: CRAN compliance version re CITATION

title: palaeoSig 2.1-0
text: New vignette showing use red-noise null model randomTF(). Changed h-block cross-validation use sf package geographic data (rather sp).

title: palaeoSig 2.1-0
text: rne() now several orders magnitude faster.

title: palaeoSig 2.1-0
text: randomTF(), species fossil data automatically transformed matrices done , every iteration. sometimes failed MAT. Now step recommended help file. Sometimes great-circle distances point , calculated fields::rdist.earth(), non-zero due rounding errors. lead excluded h-block resampling rne() threshold distance zero. Now diagonal distance matrix set zero, removing problem.

title: palaeoSig 2.0-8
text: randomTF(), argument col missing, columns reconstruction used, lazy evaluation done use formula. Code now check col set needed.

title: palaeoSig 2.0-7

text: MAT shortcut now works autosim set

title: palaeoSig 2.0-1

title: palaeoSig 2.0-1
text: plotting functions p.val becomes p_val p-value rather percentile null distribution functionality modelMaker randomTFmm (can used calibration set used many cores) moved within randomTF

title: palaeoSig 2.0-1
text: Lot sanity checks inputs randomTF obs.cor randomTF now accepts vector environmemtal data randomTF obs.cor permute argument permutes environmental variable rather simulating one uniform distribution. possible single environmental variable.

title: palaeoSig 2.0-1
text: autoplot functions output randomTF obs.cor

title: palaeoSig 2.0-1

title: Changes in version 1.1
text: RNE replaces function mat.rne, mat.mat.rd. RNE allows transfer function methods  used find dependence transfer function performance spatially close observations. plot.RNE replaces plot.rne work output RNE. obs.cor replaces previous version obs.cor, sim.cor obscor.sig make function easier use similar randomTF plot.obscor replaces previous version plot.obscor plot.simcor use new output obs.cor. two plot types can selected argument . jointsig: tests two environmental variables joint control fossil assemblage composition. plot.js: plot function jointsig Hill.N2.core now calculates Minimum, first quartile median effective number species fossil observations. makes much sense previous version, conflated diversity individual levels turnover levels. plot.palaeoSig improved give neater figures.

title: Changes in version 1.1
text: wajack removed WA now implemented .

title: Changes in version 1.1
